title: Effect of Charge and Magnetic Field on Particle

content.question:
This question is a long free-response question. Show your work for each part of the question. (15 points, suggested time 25 minutes)

A potential difference <math alttext="uppercase V" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>V</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> exists between two parallel plates that are separated by a distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>d</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. A particle of mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>m</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and charge <math alttext="positive q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is accelerated from rest through the potential difference, and as a result moves between the plates in a straight line in the plane of the page, as shown above. The particle reaches the right-hand plate with a speed <math alttext="lowercase v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, passes through a hole in the plate, and enters a region containing a uniform magnetic field. The particle then follows the semicircular path shown. Gravitational effects are negligible.

(a) Would the speed <math alttext="lowercase v" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the particle be greater, smaller, or the same if the magnitude of the particle’s charge was greater? Explain your answer.

(b) A student derives the equation <math alttext="lowercase v equals, the fraction with numerator 2 times q, times uppercase V, and denominator m times d, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>q</mi><mi>V</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>m</mi><mi>d</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> for the speed of the particle. Whether or not the equation is correct, is it consistent with your answer to part (a)? Explain your reasoning.

(c) A student equates the following two expressions to determine how an increase in the magnitude of the magnetic field affects the radius of its path in the field.
<math alttext="m times lowercase v squared, divided by r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mi>m</mi><msup><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mstyle></math> for the magnitude of the net force on an object in uniform circular motion with radius <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>
<math alttext="q times lowercase v, times B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>q</mi><mi>v</mi><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the magnitude of the force on a charged particle in a magnetic field of magnitude <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>
Describe the relationship between the magnetic field magnitude and the radius of the particle’s path indicated by these expressions, and indicate how an increase in the magnetic field affects the radius.

(d) Another student writes the equation <math alttext="r equals, the square root of, the fraction with numerator 2 times uppercase V, times m, and denominator open parenthesis, B squared, plus q times uppercase V, close parenthesis, end fraction, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>V</mi><mi>m</mi></mrow><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><msup><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>q</mi><mi>V</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mfrac></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>for the radius of the path. Whether or not the equation is correct, is it consistent with your answer to part (c)? Explain your reasoning.

(e) An electric field can be applied in the region containing the magnetic field that will cause the particle to have a component of motion out of the page (toward the reader). What is the direction of such an electric field? Justify your answer.

The region of the magnetic field is replaced by a wire that is in the page and has a current directed toward the top of the page (as seen above). The particle still moves in a straight line between the plates.

(f) With respect to the coordinate axes shown, in what direction is the acceleration of the particle at the instant it passes through the hole? Explain your reasoning.
